body:
@overdrive80 
You can define any locale at: **branding window -> Internationalization Resourse Bundles**
and then just copy a new properties file, for example: Bundle_pt_BR.properties

I dont't know why all old translations except english are lost in current versions of NB.
Also there is exist some translations at github:

- https://github.com/borisheithecker/netbeans-translations-de
- https://github.com/junichi11/netbeans-translations-ja
- https://github.com/hanhairizhi/netbeans-translations-zh_CN

To get all string keys you can get all _Bundle.properties_ files from NB source code.

> @overdrive80 
> You can define any locale at: **branding window -> Internationalization Resourse Bundles**
> and then just copy a new properties file, for example: Bundle_pt_BR.properties
> 
> I dont't know why all old translations except english are lost in current versions of NB.
> Also there is exist some translations at github:
> 
> - https://github.com/borisheithecker/netbeans-translations-de
> - https://github.com/junichi11/netbeans-translations-ja
> - https://github.com/hanhairizhi/netbeans-translations-zh_CN
> 
> To get all string keys you can get all _Bundle.properties_ files from NB source code.

Using the batch script I extracted all the bundle.properties but it was necessary to translate them all again.

If I mixed the old translations with the new resources, the IDE did not apply the translations correctly. The paths to the bundles in many cases has a pattern: org.... In others it doesn't.

I don't know how this project doesn't have another way to internationalise, e.g. using po files or similar tools (sphinx or transifex).

The experience was frustrating and I have stopped translating it.

it was deliberately changed in #5760 to use the standard icons (again) for consistency reasons, but it can be still customized via properties if you like the FlatLaf icons:

`tools -> options -> appearance -> flatlaf -> edit custom properties`

and add:
```properties
Tree.closedIcon = com.formdev.flatlaf.icons.FlatTreeClosedIcon
Tree.openIcon = com.formdev.flatlaf.icons.FlatTreeOpenIcon
```

![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1381701/e81ab645-e7d9-4343-9d70-81b35230ff5d)

Further cleanup, removed the option to select the Gradle version, added default Java Runtime selection for Gradle execution.

There could be further enhancements, around warnings and auto selecting the proper JDK for Gradle Execution, but this is how far I could go before NB20 window closes.
I don't mind. Thanks!

Ok, O downloaded  ( I was loged in) and I managed to debug with chrome dev tools.
Thanks a lot!.

Will this patch be imported in the next version (20)?

as discussed on apache slack, going to add a commit which fixes some minor layout issues. Some show up right away, some are only visible when the window is resized:
![layout-issues-gradle1](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/0d3033e2-0c3d-43ff-bd21-edc1daaf3a9a)

![layout-issues-gradle3](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/6300d35a-db69-4455-aeee-09e3aaf340ca)
![layout-issues-gradle4](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/2adabc36-5754-4410-a9c5-4dbebf145ae3)
If you're going to have to keep pushing into this PR, please re-open from a branch on your clone, thanks!
i canceled some of the branch workflows, while leaving the PR workflow running.

You can override the IDE actions to run whatever Maven tasks you want in project properties.  This is similar to the JavaFX plugin situation.

I'm not sure we should be changing defaults heuristically based on active plugins.  Ideally there would be a standard Maven way to communicate this information.
@mbien only reason I refrained from that is it marks as failing tests on the PR.

@neilcsmith-net it will show up as canceled, the other workflow run should be green. There should be no red in the list of the checks even though if the title says "some checks wewre not successfull".

Another way to verify this is by pressing details and looking at the workflow run itself.

Sorry, should have said that this is in the context of the VS Code extension. 

Unfortunately, there is no way to customise that workflow on the IDE.
@sdedic if this is ready to merge, please squash / clean up (remove println) so that we can get this in before freeze.
Ah, OK, maybe @sdedic or @MartinBalin can comment on this.  Is it implemented but not easily findable, or a feature request?
Based on my search of the code, i think it's not implemented, so a feature request. Unless someone knows where to find it.
I think the "do not merge" label can be removed; this PR is ready to be committed except for a minor requested change.

Have you checked if `nbactions.xml` files work?  See https://bits.netbeans.org/19/javadoc/org-netbeans-modules-maven/architecture-summary.html#group-java.io.File

Otherwise I'll leave someone who knows the extension more to answer.
I'm seeing this still happening on NB 19.
So reopening it?
Yes please, sorry--it takes me a while to get back to PRs, as switching/recompiling branches of the netbeans repo is a multi-hour operation on my Windows machine...

Removed the `do not merge` as I realised that's something I added when moving things around with NB17.

If @eirikbakke @DevCharly and/or @mbien want to reopen and re-review, then it can be reopened.  I'm just closing a few things that have bumped along from milestone to milestone without getting any further towards resolution.

> as switching/recompiling branches of the netbeans repo is a multi-hour operation on my Windows machine...

:open_mouth: what's going on there?  It's a 7min operation on my machine.  That might be something to look into?!

just my opinion but I am not convinced that the icon position needs to be adjusted. If you run a picture search for "error dialog", or take a look at the examples I posted somewhere above, you will see that it is fairly common that the icon is anchored in the NW corner.

NB has many layout bugs though, some dialogs might be too large and need to be adjusted so that the components don't float around, some might contain hidden components which break the layout manager (see screenshot of #6355).

(and yes building NB takes about 7,5 mins on my PC I built ~2016 -> there must be something wrong)

It's WSL 1 on Windows, on a 2018 laptop, with the NetBeans repo on a Windows file system (WSL 1 is actually faster than WSL 2 in this case). "git checkout" takes several minutes, "git status" takes 18 seconds, and a clean build will hog up the machine long enough that I usually break for dinner...

I'll be switching to a new MacBook soon, though. Having a native UNIX terminal, no Windows Defender, and new hardware will make everything much faster.
> just my opinion but I am not convinced that the icon position needs to be adjusted. I think this is clearly wrong:

^ the dialog size is wrong I agree -> https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5335#issuecomment-1399324873

(the layout does its job if the size is properly adjusted)
@mbien I think this was all discussed before, but if you prefer I can just leave this unmerged.
Moving to my clone

lets take a look at another dialog which displays a panel with sub-optimal layout management:
![warning-before](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/f0ff8166-3567-46d3-821c-6ccf51830ede)
->
![warning-after](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/a6d9a765-f2e8-4d58-813e-540ba519ce86)
all I did was to quickly fix the content which used grid bag layout, the dialog is unchanged. It used empty panels for padding, couldn't properly calculate its default size and the gaps were not set for the purpose of it being included into a dialog etc

`netbeans/ide/projectui/src/org/netbeans/modules/project/ui/problems/BrokenReferencesAlertPanel.java`

actually... let me open a PR for this :) (edit: #6575)
Cleaned up

Completely forgot about this, apologies.
Two options: merge into the release "as is" & improve implementation in master as suggested by @mbien or plan to rebase this on delivery as soon as it is created. I don't think I'll make it in the remaining time with at least one re-approval.

The fixed bug is really ugly on throwaway VMs in virtual classes.

I am not sure if merging this so late is a good idea. We did something like this before and had to revert the PR since it caused side effects. There is always the next release.

also I would prefer to switch to a minimal reproducer if possible, instead of importing a full third party sample project. Since this is about priming, i suppose the java code outside of placeholder classes isn't even needed. This is just my opinion, not a veto.
that was quick, since its already reviewed, lets get this in for NB 20 :)
@ChristoforosKor thank you for the check. No this will not make it for NB20. I'll have to get back into the PR, rereview it and get it into a mergeable state.
Ah, I see, just for one specific dialog. Great!
This PR is needed for 20 as it fixes misbehaviour of NetBeans in loading Maven project. The code in PR is tested. We will target this to `delivery` and then to NB20.

Adding `do not merge` until ready, both branch and some issues.

I agree with @mbien about the concerns of merging late, and of the test project.  The binary Maven wrapper should not be in the repository (switch to source-only wrapper) and I have concerns about the licensing of the test project files.  If this is truly needed, can it be published externally for consumption?
Approved, thank you for making this change

@neilcsmith-net, it would be awesome if this could be included in NB 20. I am sorry I am late, but there's unfortunately only a small window in which we can get this patch in (as it will break some outside components, so it is necessary give them time to adjust), and I unfortunately was not able to finish this in the past 2-3 weeks. Thanks for your consideration!

>  I have concerns about the licensing of the test project files. If this is truly needed, can it be published externally for consumption?

Re. the test project sources: these are just generated (including the LICENSE file) from `https://www.graal.cloud/gcn/launcher/`, which is freely available to everyone. Does it answer the licensing issue ?

The test sources are marked (c) Oracle, so possibly need registering to be picked up in the source notice bundle (cc/ @matthiasblaesing - not sure how tests fit into that).

The Maven wrapper jar is a release blocker.

> The test sources are marked (c) Oracle, so possibly need registering to be picked up in the source notice bundle (cc/ @matthiasblaesing - not sure how tests fit into that).
> 

OK, if that's an issue, should I create my own project from scratch just following the wizard's project structure ?

> The Maven wrapper jar is a release blocker.

Will try to change to source, or get rid of wrapper. Thanks.

> OK, if that's an issue, should I create my own project from scratch just following the wizard's project structure ?

for the purpose of testing the priming code, the most important part is the pom. I believe the source code can be mostly reduced to placeholder classes, the launchers are probably not needed at all most likely.
draft for one-liners: #6577

This breaks the release build.  Should probably have been `cluster.config.release.list` or something that picks up the configured cluster config - `nb.clusters.list`?

There will be no release candidate of the VSCode plugin for 20-rc1, and until this can be fixed on delivery.

cc/ @MartinBalin

Support in VSNetBeans for Micronaut proper `Run | Debug | Run Continuous Dev Mode` is provided by Micronaut NetBeans plugin. This will have to be written specifically for SpringBoot and I don't think SpringBoot has NetBeans plugin. There are likely different ways how to achieve this in NetBeans. 
Few observations for SpringBoot/VSCode and JDT. SpringBoot is dependent on JDT and when I last looked at that they don't solve correct SpringBoot way of `Run | Debug` either as code lenses or as Run configs in VSCode. I think they simply assume you run it from VSCode terminal. It could changed as it is a while when I looked at SpringBoot VSIX.

Here are some things that I saw in the code:
[java/java.lsp.server/nbcode/integration/src/org/netbeans/modules/nbcode/integration/layer.xml](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/0a109c22b96d62af455b13cbb304acdaa2f014f7/java/java.lsp.server/nbcode/integration/src/org/netbeans/modules/nbcode/integration/layer.xml#L166)
In this file, there is a reference to the `spring-actions-override.xml` but there is no such file. There is, though:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/0a109c22b96d62af455b13cbb304acdaa2f014f7/java/java.lsp.server/nbcode/integration/src/org/netbeans/modules/nbcode/integration/spring-actions-override.xml#L4

Also, the `spring-actions-override.xml` only has an override for the native action. I created a nbactions.xml, and could get the "rebuild" and "debug" targets to run with the "Debug" and "Compile" actions in the VSCode extension. I could also, not get the debugger to attach to the "spring-boot:run" command, even though VS Code "Notifications" shows the "Debug", and waits for it to terminate. Either because I am passing the arguments wrong, or the below message actually does mean something:
```
--- spring-boot:3.1.4:run (default-cli) @ myapp ---
Attaching agents: []
```

So, I am guessing, that there is already some basic integration with Spring. Just needs to be enhanced a bit. 

@MartinBalin You are right about the Spring VS Code extension needing the JDT enabled Java LS extension. But then, they have no incentive to change that behaviour immediately. A small change, similar to the one I have in the nbactions.xml , would go a long way from where we are right now. It is no "Spring Dashboard", but still.

[nbactions.xml.zip](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/12929710/nbactions.xml.zip)

This is, by no means, even close to being a merge request, just a sample.

Let me know if I can help.

For one-line messages I think it's actually good to have a bit of margin above and below the message; it makes the dialog more readable. There naturally ends up being whitespace under the message (because there is a lot of empty space to the left of the OK button), but not above with the new configuration.

Yes, might not want to do this on every run.

We really need to have building the VSCode plugin tied in to the release cluster build here too. Given that's the failure that prompted this.

> Yes, might not want to do this on every run.

yep, had the same thoughts


> We really need to have building the VSCode plugin tied in to the release cluster build here too. Given that's the failure that prompted this.

this might be the missing puzzle piece:
```yml
  CLUSTER_CONFIG: ${{ (contains(github.event.pull_request.labels.*.name, 'rust') || github.event_name != 'pull_request') && 'full' || 'release' }}
```
we are so lucky that fake ternary ops work! We could build the full cluster only when `rust` is specified in PRs? What should happen on the master branch, post-merge?

edit: discussed this on slack a bit and we going to leave it on the `full` cluster config for now
well.. that job was supposed to fail. Lets stash this and try it plan b.

Not reproduced with latest windows build with java 18.0.2
![изображение](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/16633367/cf7a5ba7-2186-4147-a3c3-ccfd788ee913)
This will brake Java EE/Jakarta EE 8 and prior projects, maybe add another Library called Jersey 3.x.y?

After switching to NetBeans 18, I started to see a spurious "Checking for external changes" message when exiting the NetBeans IDE. I also see this message in my NetBeans Platform app, which should not be watching any files at all. Using the debugger, the process that's running seems to be the one in MenuWarmUpTask (which confusingly contains refresh-on-window-activation logic in addition to menu warmup tasks), which was last touched by this PR. Could there be some difference in the behavior of ProgressHandle.createHandle vs. ProgressHandleFactory.createHandle that causes the task to never register as complete?
I agree with @OndroMih. Jakarta EE 9/9.1/10 does not support EJB 3.2 and prior because it will not compile, even if the only change is the namespace, xml, and xds files.
@neilcsmith-net OK to merge, or do you do merging to delivery? (Sorry, the process is not completely clear to me.) Thanks!
no luck with reproducing the jenkins issue

I haven't checked for what this is used for internally, but if its just a lib wrapper for ant projects (I have the suspicion it is more than that), i would update it to the latest javax release and leave it there.
https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/ee4j.jersey/releases/2.40
In the future it would be useful to provide more info about failure. Link to failed build and steps to reproduce. Not everyone if familiar with release process.

Thanks @thurka While we wait for tests here, could you confirm that building the VSCode plugin from the source bundle at https://nightlies.apache.org/netbeans/candidate/netbeans/ fails, and that making this change in there fixes it?
The PR, which probably can fix the vsix build, is here: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/6583

I tried yesterday to reproduce this with github actions so that this can't happen anymore in future (#6579, #6580) but the jobs were green unfortunately.

So if anyone has an idea, contact me and I add it.

@thurka have added a comment on your PR about testing with the source bundle.

The git repository includes clusters in the full configuration that are not (yet) intended for release.  The build server first builds a source bundle of the releasable clusters, then builds binaries from that bundle (which does not include all the clusters in the full configuration).

We're currently discussing on ASF slack how we can test for this.

To replicate the process locally, run `ant build-source-config` on the repo, then use the resulting zip for a binary build.
@mbien you have to run `ant build-source-config` then use the contents of the resulting zip to build the binaries. First PR doesn't try and build VSCode that way, and second PR just changes clusters.

> This will brake Java EE/Jakarta EE 8 and prior projects, maybe add another Library called Jersey 3.x.y?

Can we ship two Jersey versions without having conflicts?

At some point we will have to upgrade to Jersey 3. Not sure if it's the right moment to do so.
As a side note, I think that the Jersey version shipped by websvc.restlib breaks the REST Client plugin. See #6566.

> could you confirm

Yes.

```
 BUILD FAILED
/home/runner/work/netbeans/netbeans/tmpbuild/java/java.lsp.server/build.xml:131: Cannot resolve rust.cargo. Neither one exist:
  /home/runner/work/netbeans/netbeans/tmpbuild/rust.cargo
  /home/runner/work/netbeans/netbeans/tmpbuild/rust/rust.cargo
Total time: 2 minutes 44 seconds
Error: Process completed with exit code 1.
```
it worked! success!
Never been happier to see failing tests! :smile:

I made an implementation overhaul of the PR, based on the feedback.

1. implementation reworked: blocking tasks are kept in a queue. Queue's emptiness is checked upon completion of each task.
2. I've added quite a few tests to cover different scenarios of delayed / forced / no reload requests
3. I've recreated the test project data from scratch, with just a skeleton of project directories. None of the files should now contain copyright other than ASF or references to oracle except artifact names.

I will probably add back some basic classes in the future, and add more tests that will check diagnostics in the opened projects, i.e. no unresolved symbols in files.

I kindly ask all reviewers to re-review.
@tmysik Thank you for your time and your review! (Sorry for the huge change... I've added unit tests as much as possible.) Will fix them tomorrow or later.

You can have different versions of the same library, check the Ant Library, there are different versions for JSF and Spring:
![Screenshot from 2023-10-18 11-58-52](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/9832133/233073a2-2074-4410-88f1-6058e76187c5)
I do not think it is as a matter of "upgrade" but of "support", we should support Jersey 2 for Java/Jakarta EE 8 and prior and add support for Jersey 3 for Jakarta EE 9 and onward.

I agree with @mbien, we should update it to the latest 2.x version.

I found that it works in a simple project but it does not work with other complex project. The surefire output is the same and both are Spring projects. Can you try to make simple maven project with one test and run it? Just to confirm it.

No, I know, I swear I was just looking at code with that method in, but certainly can't find it now.  :shrug: 

Having a look at an alternative idea.  Our library is an old release too.

OK... some explanation before I clean up the code again:
no race condition, but it turned out that the Micronaut4 tests can only run on JDK17+ - a Micronaut LifevcycleParticipant injected into Maven infrastructure in MN 4.0+ version is compiled for JDK17 and above. Then any Maven run on JDK11 fail during project model building phase, and even fails to download all artifacts -- which causes projects in NB to fail to load again, which ultimately asserts the test.

I would appreciate to run these tests (since MN4 has quite weird project structure with all the BOMs etc) - and in addition other Oracle work focuses on Micronaut ... and it's a reasonably complex application library to use as test data.

So I'd like to run build tools on **both** JDK11 and JDK17 as the behaviour of Gradle/Maven may differ on different JDKs.

Came to similar conclusion. https://github.com/apache/netbeans/compare/master...neilcsmith-net:netbeans:disco-nb20rc

Not sure why that method returns a `Boolean` but guarded against it.

Not the first time we've had issues with the EA filter being wrong.

EDIT : could also rewrite the cache in there to include the EA and filter that. https://github.com/apache/netbeans/compare/master...neilcsmith-net:netbeans:disco-nb20rc2
